etymologies: late Middle English; earliest use found in Lanfranc's Science of Cirurgie. From classical Latin rotula small wheel, in post-classical Latin also kneecap from rota wheel + -ula

definitions: A mechanical device showing the motion of the sun and moon and their position for each day of the year. More fully "astronomical rotula".

notes.text: The astronomical rotula was devised by the Scottish inventor James Ferguson (1710–76).

definitions: A keyhole urchin or sand dollar of the West African genus Rotula (order Clypeasteroida), having a round, flattened test with deep notches along the edge. Also (in form Rotula): the genus itself.
Each of five radial elements forming part of the oral apparatus (Aristotle's lantern) of echinoids.

notes.text: They are elongated in shape in regular echinoids, but were named by Des Moulins (1835) from the more discoid structures that he observed in clypeasteroids (sand dollars).

definitions: A circular structure forming the end of some sponge spicules; = "rotule". Also: a wheel-shaped spicule in the integument of certain holothurians.
